data.title: THE FIGHTING ‘HAT BOX’

data.text:
During World War Two, HMS Argus was at the centre of some of the Royal Navy’s most important operations. However, as Dr Alexander Clarke describes, this outdated conversion had already changed maritime history

HMS Argus was a conversion, a compromise, a contingency. By World War Two she was, in the view of any contemporary commentator, hopelessly outclassed. Yet she served, was of use and acquitted herself with honour in roles assigned. The wartime service of this unique, pioneering aircraft carrier – the first ship built to the pattern we would recognise today as such – would include Operations Harpoon, Pedestal, Torch and White. Her peacetime service was no less distinguished – involving the China Station and the Chanak Crisis. Argus was a vessel like no other, tracing her origins back to 1912 and the first conceptions of an aircraft carrier. It was in that year the Royal Navy started considering how to recover and reuse aircraft at sea.
